questions.text: During pregnancy there is increased demand for calcium, as the fetus accures about 30 g of calcium for building its own skeleton. Which of the following maternal changes is responsible for meeting this increased demand?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased production of cortisol from the adrenal glands

options.label: D
options.text: Enhanced intestinal calcium absorption due to increased calcitriol levels

questions.correct_answer: D. Enhanced intestinal calcium absorption due to increased calcitriol levels
questions.explanation:
ENDOCRINE CHANGES IN PREGNANCY

INCREASE

DECREASE

UNCHANGED
  • Prolactin
  • Growth Hormone
  • ACTH
  • Cortisol
  • Aldosterone
  • Testosterone
  • Calcitriol
  • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG)
  • Total T4
  • Total T3
  • hCG
  • Human placental lactogen (hPL)
  • Insulin
  • PTH
  • Calcitonin
  • FSH
  • LH
  • DHEAS (Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate)
  • Free T3
  • Free T4
  • Vasopressin (ADH)

questions.text: Arrange the following antenatal investigation in sequential order: Triple marker test Nuchal translucency scan Growth scan Anomaly scan
Which of the following vaccines can a pregnant woman receive?
questions.explanation:
Vaccines contraindicated in pregnancy

(Option A, C and D)
  • Measles
  • Mumps
  • Rubella
  • Varicella
  • Smallpox
  • Zoster

Used in high risk of contracting infection
  • Polio
  • Yellow fever
  • Influenza (Option B)
  • Rabies
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis A
  • Pneumococcus
  • Meningococcus
  • Typhoid
  • Anthrax

Not recommended
  • HPV

Recommeneded
  • Tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis

questions.text: A lady who is 24 weeks pregnant came to the OPD for routine antenatal check up. She has a history of normal twin delivery 3 years back and 2 abortions. What is is her obstetric score?
questions.explanation:
Gravida

Denotes a pregnant state, both present and past, irrespective ofthe  period of gestation

Parity

Denotes a state of previous pregnancy beyond the period of viability(28 weeks)

Abortion

Number of pregnancies lost before 24 weeks

Living

Living children

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was recorded as February 15, 2024. She reports regular 28-day menstrual cycles. What is her estimated delivery date (EDD)?
Which of the following pairs of placental hormones and their function is incorrectly matched?

options.label: B
options.text: Beta HCG - Maintains corpus luteum function

options.label: D
options.text: Human Placental Lactogen - Helps in maternal adaptation to fetal energy requirements.

questions.explanation:
Placental hormones

Extra placental sites of secretion

Functions

Human chorionic gonadotropin

(Option B)

  

Released exclusively from the placenta.
  • Maintains corpus luteum function
  • Regulates fetal testis testosterone secretion
  • Stimulate maternal thyroid secretion

Human Placental lactogen

(Option D)
  • Helps in maternal adaptation to fetal energy requirements

Inhibin

(Option A)

  

Ovaries/testis.
  • Inhibits FSH-mediated ovulation
  • Inhibin from placenta also regulates hCG synthesis.

 

  

Growth hormone hCG variant

Released exclusively from the placenta.
  • Mediates pregnancy insulin resistance.

questions.text: Which cell type in the placenta is primarily responsible for producing human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and human placental lactogen (hPL)?
During fetal development, which of the following accurately represents the time period of development of the tertiary villus?
At approximately what gestational age is the development of the placenta generally completed?
questions.explanation:
Day 11-13
  • Placental development begins with the blastocyst implanting into the uterine wall by day 11, leading to lacunar spaces and trabeculae forming by day 13.
  • Stem villi develop from trabeculae, establishing connections between the chorionic and basal plates.

Day 21
  • Villi develop arterio-capillary-venous systems that connect with the embryonic circulation via the body stalk.

3-4 weeks
  • Lacunar spaces merge to form intervillous spaces, which fill with maternal blood.

Week 6
  • The decidua capsularis begins to thin, while the chorion frondosum and decidua basalis undergo robust growth, culminating in the formation of the placenta by week 12.

questions.text: Which of the following adaptations describes dynamic changes in the uterus during pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: The uterus increases in weight by approximately 50 grams by the end of the first trimester.

options.label: B
options.text: Uterine size remains unchanged until the third trimester when it begins to enlarge rapidly.

options.label: C
options.text: The capacity of the uterus increases by 500-1000 times at the end of the third trimester

options.label: D
options.text: Uterine size decreases progressively after the second trimester

questions.correct_answer: C. The capacity of the uterus increases by 500-1000 times at the end of the third trimester

questions.text: A 28-y/o woman at 32 weeks gestation complains of occasional indigestion, bloating and painful bulges around the anus with occasional rectal bleeding. Her LFTs reveal double the nonpregnant levels of serum ALP, with normal levels of ALT and AST and normal bile acid levels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

A 28-y/o woman in her 32nd week of gestation presents with urinary frequency. Which of the following physiological changes in the urinary system during pregnancy is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Kidney

Ureter

Bladder

Dilatation of ureters, renal pelvis, and calyces

Ureters become atonic due to high progesterone

Marked congestion and hypertrophy of the wall

Renal plasma flow increases by 50–75% (max at 16 weeks)

Dilation and stasis, especially on the right side

Increased micturition at 6–8 weeks, subsides after 12 weeks

GFR increases by 50%, reducing plasma creatinine, BUN, uric acid

Elongation and kinking of ureters

Late pregnancy leads to increased frequency due to pressure

Tubules fail to reabsorb glucose, uric acid, amino acids, and vitamins

Muscle hypertrophy in the pelvic part

Stress incontinence may occur in late pregnancy

questions.text: Which factor contributes significantly to the hypercoagulable state observed in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Clotting Factor

Change during pregnancy

Fibrinogen

Increased

II, VII, VIII, IX, X and I

Increased

II, V, and XII

Unchanged or mildly increased

XI and XIII

Decreased

questions.text: All of the following are normal cardiovascular changes during pregnancy EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Systolic flow murmur over the tricuspid area

options.label: C
options.text: Fixed split of second heart sound (S2)

options.label: D
options.text: Systolic flow murmur over pulmonary area

questions.correct_answer: C. Fixed split of second heart sound (S2)
questions.explanation:
Category

Change

Description

Clinical Implication

Hemodynamics

↑ Cardiac Output

Increases by 40–50% due to ↑ stroke volume and ↑ heart rate

Ensures adequate perfusion to uterus, placenta, and maternal organs

↑ Heart Rate

Rises by 15–30% above baseline

Compensatory response to increased circulatory demands

↓ Systemic Vascular Resistance

Falls by 25–40% from vasodilation (mediated by nitric oxide, prostaglandins)

Causes drop in BP during early pregnancy

↓ Blood Pressure (initially)

Falls in 1st and 2nd trimesters, returns to baseline by term

Due to decreased SVR; important for monitoring preeclampsia

↑ Blood Volume (especially plasma)

Expands significantly, elevating preload

Supports fetal circulation; may cause flow murmurs

Cardiac Structure

↑ LV Size and Remodeling

LV mass ↑ ~30–35% near term; ↑ chamber dimensions without EF or septal changes

Normal remodeling process in pregnancy 

Auscultatory Changes

Heart Sounds

• Exaggerated splitting and louder S1

• No change in aortic/pulmonary S2

• Loud S3 

All are normal findings on auscultation during pregnancy

Murmurs

• Common: soft systolic ejection murmurs

• Occasional: soft diastolic or continuous (mammary) murmurs

Typically benign; must differentiate from pathological murmurs 

Positional Effects

Postural Changes

Supine hypotension from IVC compression in late pregnancy

May cause dizziness/syncope; alleviated by left lateral positioning

questions.text: A 28 y/o primigravida, currently in her third trimester, presents to the clinic complaining of dizziness and shortness of breath, especially when lying on her back. She feels better when she shifts to her left side. What is the condition likely due to?
Which hormone is primarily responsible for the proliferation of the ducts in the breasts during early pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Hormone

Function

Estrogen (Option B)
  • Proliferation of the ducts and alveoli
  • Growth and branching of the ductal system, causing increased size of the breasts.
Progesterone (Option A)

Development of the alveoli in the breasts
Prolactin (Option C)
  • Production and secretion of milk after childbirth.
  • Maintenance of effective and continuous lactation
Oxytocin (Option D)
  • Milk ejection reflex or let-down reflex during breastfeeding.
  • It causes the myoepithelial cells to contract and expel milk from the alveoli into the ducts.

questions.text: Match the following statements with the right option. 1. Chadwick's sign a. Increased pulsations felt through lateral fornices. 2. Goodell’s sign b. Softening of Cervix. 3. Osiander's sign c. Bluish hue of the vaginal wall. 4. Hegar's sign d. Abdominal & vaginal fingers oppose below the body of the uterus.
questions.explanation:
Early Signs of Pregnancy

Description

Cause

Week of Pregnancy

Hegar's sign

Softening of the lower uterine segment

Increased vascularity and relaxation of the smooth muscle

6-8 weeks of gestation

Chadwick's sign (Jacquemier’s sign)

 

Bluish discoloration of the cervix and vagina

Increased vascularity in response to hormonal changes in pregnancy.

8th week

Goodell's sign

Softening of the cervix

Increased vascularization and edema.

6th week

Piskacek's sign

Asymmetric enlargement of the uterus

Lateral implantation of fertilized ovum

-

Palmer's sign

Regular and rhythmic uterine contractions

Due to increased estrogen levels, and the physiological adaptations of the uterus preparing for labor

4-8 weeks

Osiander's sign

Increased pulsations felt through lateral fornices

Increased blood flow uterus by the uterine arteries

8th-12th week

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a type of normal cervical change during pregnancy?
